TEST #4 on Logarithmic Functions TODAY!!!
Be sure to finish the Test 4 Review Packet.
Answer Key for Review

Practice for the test. You may use a calculator on only part of the test, and both sides of a 3"-by-5" notecard (which you have prepared in your own handwriting) on the entire test. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day, and you must arrange for your extended time beforehand.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
     1. Tell whether a function is linear, exponential, quadratic, power, or none of these.
     2. Apply exponential functions as models of real-world phenomena.
     3. Find the common ratio (growth factor) from exponential data.
     4. Apply the properties of exponents and logarithms.
     5. Represent functions as algebraic rules (formulas), tables, graphs, and function machines.
     6. Distinguish exponential from power equations, and solve both.
     7. Represent exponential functions as their graphs and vice versa.
     8. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

As preparation, you should go over all your recent quizzes, handouts, and homework, as well as your Test #3.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Practice for the test. You may use a calculator on part of the test, and both sides of a 3"-by-5" notecard (which you have prepared in your own handwriting) on the entire test. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day, and you must arrange for your extended time beforehand.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Tell whether a function is linear, exponential, quadratic, power, or none of these.
  2. Apply exponential functions as models of real-world phenomena.
  3. Find the common ratio (growth factor) from exponential data.
  4. Apply the properties of exponents and logarithms.
  5. Represent functions as algebraic rules (formulas), tables, graphs, and function machines.
  6. Distinguish exponential from power equations, and solve both.
  7. Represent translated exponential functions as their graphs and vice versa.
  8. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.
As preparation, you should go over all your recent quizzes, handouts, and homework, as well as your Test #3. If you want/need additional practice problems, try this review packet written by a former teacher several years ago. It's not a perfect match, but it's extremely close: just change "Scheme" to "NetLogo" in question #3, change "evaluate" to "solve" in question #11, and note that the author does not always parenthesize the input to a log function. Answers will be posted on Wednesday.

2. Apply exponential functions as models of real-world phenomena.

Practice for the test. You may use a calculator on the test, and a one-sided 3"-by-5" notecard (which you have prepared in your own handwriting) on the entire test. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day, and you must arrange for your extended time beforehand.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
     1. Solve systems of linear and/or non-linear equations by graphing.
     2. Solve systems of linear and/or non-linear equations by substitution.
     3. Solve systems of linear equations by elimination.
     4. Write a system of equations from a word problem or story problem and solve it in the prescribed way in order to show your work.
     5. Recognize and create situations where there are no solutions or infinite solutions.
     6. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Celebrate Pi Day and practice for the test by redoing old problems from tests, quizzes, classwork, and homework. Also, check out the lessons on matrices that we looked at in class. You can find the Table of Contents in the left sidebar; everything is relevant except for the lesson on linear equations and the end of the lesson on determinants. Here are some practice problems, mostly related to that website. Answers are available here.

On the test you may use both sides of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. If you are legally entitled to extra time, remember that you must complete the entire test within the same day and that you must arrange your extra time in advance.

You will be well prepared if you can do all of the following:
  1. Solve systems of linear equations by graphing, substitution, and elimination.
  2. Write a system of equations from a word problem or story problem and solve it in the prescribed way in order to show your work.
  3. Add and subtract matrices, and identify when these operations are possible.
  4. Multiply a matrix by a scalar.
  5. Multiply matrices, and identify when this operation is possible.
  6. Solve equations involving matrices.
  7. Identify elements and dimensions of matrices.
  8. Find and use the determinant of a matrix (2×2 without a calculator, other matrices with); identify which matrices have determinants.
  9. Find and use the inverse of a matrix (2×2 without a calculator, other matrices with); identify which matrices have inverses.
  10. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
     1. Solve systems of linear and/or non-linear equations by graphing.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Test today! The test will cover matrices as well as systems of equations. In particular, you have to be able to perform basic matrix operations (addition, scalar multiplication, and multiplication--which we call "matrixification"), find determinants, identities, and inverses for square matrices, and understand the concepts of identity and inverse.
For practice, do this worksheet, which refers to the lessons on this helpful website.

  2. Carefully study Using Matrices to Solve Linear Systems, which we worked through in class.

  3. Complete Matrices IV: Systems of Linear Equations and Matrices. Be sure to remember that a variable without a visible coefficient actually has a coefficient of 1.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Practice for the test by redoing old problems from tests, quizzes, classwork, and homework. On the test you may use both sides of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. If you are legally entitled to extra time, remember that you must complete the entire test within the same day and that you must arrange your extra time in advance.

You will be well prepared if you can do all of the following:
  1. Encipher and decipher with substitution ciphers.
  2. Encipher and decipher with Caesar ciphers.
  3. Encipher and decipher with affine ciphers in various mods, including identification of good and bad ciphers.
  4. Encipher with matrix ciphers in various mods, including identification of good and bad ciphers.
  5. Apply the concept of congruence classes.
  6. Apply modular arithmetic in three contexts:
    • finding reciprocals in various mods
    • using mod as a binary operation [such as 28 mod 5]
    • solving congruences [such as 3x +5 ≡ 12 (mod 4)].
  7. Advise Alice and Bob on the advantages and disadvantages of the cryptosystems (other than RSA) discussed in the Big Question.
  8. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

table.name: assignments

Over the next three weeks you will be working on two topics at the same time: RSA and your crypto project. While this might seem confusing, it's important to be engaged in both. This is partly because you'll need to take a break from time to time and refresh your thinking, but it's mostly because you'll sometimes run into a bottleneck and have to wait for a classmate before you can proceed. If you have something else you can work on, you won't be idle at such times.

Read RSA One carefully and complete all the steps. If you want to get started on RSA Two, look at assignment #76.

Also, get started on your project.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Practice for the final exam. The best way to do this is to go back over old tests and quizzes, covering up your solutions and seeing whether you can still do the problems. Redoing old assignments will also be very useful. Finally, be sure you have completed the review problems from the previous assignment.

The final exam will begin promptly at 7:50 AM in Room 7 for students with extra time, or at 8:50 AM in Room 30 for those with regular time. In either case it ends at 10:50 AM. On the exam you will be allowed to use two 3"-by-5" or 4"-by-6" notecards written in your own handwriting. We recommend one unit per notecard side, since we’ve studied four units:
  • Quadratics
  • Exponents & Logs
  • Systems of Equations & Inequalities
  • Crypto & Number Theory
Check out the cover sheet ahead of time so that the format will produce no surprises when you walk into the exam.

You will be well-prepared for the exam if you can do the following:
  1. Identify whether a function is linear, exponential, or quadratic, given an English description, a table, or an equation.

  2. Represent a linear, exponential, or quadratic function as a description, a table, and a graph, given any one of these.

  3. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.

  4. Convert quadratic functions from factored form or vertex (graphing) form to general (standard) form.

  5. Complete the square in order to convert a quadratic function from standard form to graphing form.

  6. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a quadratic function in the other three.

  7. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the prototype parabola y = x2 has been moved, and by how much.

  8. Distinguish linear, exponential, and quadratic functions by their graphs, their algebraic rules, and their tables.

  9. Distinguish exponential from power functions.

  10. Given two points (either on a graph or in a table), construct a linear and/or an exponential function passing through those points.

  11. Given an input and a function, find the output for that input.

  12. Recognize characteristic graphs of exponential and quadratic functions.

  13. Convert equations from exponential to logarithmic form and vice versa.

  14. Evaluate logarithms to any given base, using your calculator where necessary.

  15. Interpret logarithmic functions as the inverses of the corresponding exponential functions.

  16. Use logarithms to solve exponential equations and roots (or fractional exponents) to solve power equations.

  17. Use the properties of exponents to simplify expressions.

  18. Apply exponents and logarithms by constructing and using exponential models to describe read-world situations.

  19. Solve a linear equation in one variable.

  20. Graph a linear or exponential equation in two variables.

  21. Solve word problems involving systems of equations by the method of your choice.

  22. Solve a system of equations in two variables by graphing, and determine whether the equations are independent, dependent, or inconsistent.

  23. Solve a system of equations in two variables by substitution, elimination, or matrices.

  24. Find sum, difference, product, and inverse of matrices. Identify when those are nonexistent or undefined (and explain why).

  25. Solve equations in which the solutions represent matrices or variables within matrices.

  26. Graph linear inequalities.

  27. Graph systems of linear inequalities, and use the results to solve and interpret linear programming problems.

  28. Use the mod operation correctly.

  29. Encipher and decipher with Caesar, substitution, affine, matrix, and RSA ciphers. (You will not need to do the exact RSA calculations as part of the exam — you already did them outside of class in RSA Part Four — but you do need to be able to follow the steps in the process.)

  30. Determine and apply congruence classes for various moduli.

  31. Determine good and bad affine and matrix ciphers.

  32. Understand what reciprocals (multiplicative inverses) are, and apply them to the solution of congruences.

  33. Show your work and explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

You will be well prepared if you can do all of the following:
     1. Encipher and decipher with substitution ciphers.
     2. Encipher and decipher with Caesar ciphers.
     3. Encipher and decipher with affine ciphers in various mods, including identification of good and bad ciphers.
     4. Encipher with matrix ciphers in various mods, including identification of good and bad ciphers.
     5. Apply the concept of congruence classes.
     6. Apply modular arithmetic in three contexts:
         - finding reciprocals in various mods
         - using mod as a binary operation [such as 28 mod 5]
         - solving congruences [such as 3x +5 = 12 (mod 4)].
     7. Advise Alice and Bob on the advantages and disadvantages of the cryptosystems (other than RSA) discussed in the Big Question.
     8. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

Your Final Exam is on this day!

Practice for the final exam. The best way to do this is to go back over old tests and quizzes, covering up your solutions and seeing whether you can still do the problems. Redoing old assignments will also be very useful. Finally, be sure you have completed the final review packet. Answers are posted here: final review answer key

Then final exam will begin promptly at 8:50am in the following rooms:

     G block: Room 228
     H block: Room 29

     If you are a student who gets extra time(G or H block), your exam will start promptly at 7:50am in Room 7.

On the exam you will be allowed to use a calculator, and two 3"-by-5" or 4"-by-6" notecards written in your own handwriting. We recommend one unit per notecard side, since we’ve studied four units:
     * Quadratics
     * Exponents & Logs
     * Systems of Equations & Inequalities
     * Crypto & Number Theory


You will be well-prepared for the exam if you can do the following:

     1. Identify whether a function is linear, exponential, or quadratic, given an English description, a table, or an equation.
     2. Represent a linear, exponential, or quadratic function as a description, a table, and a graph, given any one of these.
     3. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
     4. Convert quadratic functions from factored form or vertex (graphing) form to general (standard) form.
     5. Complete the square in order to convert a quadratic function from standard form to graphing form.
     6. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a quadratic function in the other three.
     7. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the prototype parabola y = x2 has been moved, and by how much.
     8. Distinguish linear, exponential, and quadratic functions by their graphs, their algebraic rules, and their tables.
     9. Distinguish exponential from power functions.
     10. Given two points (either on a graph or in a table), construct a linear and/or an exponential function passing through those points.
     11. Given an input and a function, find the output for that input.
     12. Recognize characteristic graphs of exponential and quadratic functions.
     13. Convert equations from exponential to logarithmic form and vice versa.
     14. Evaluate logarithms to any given base, using your calculator where necessary.
     15. Interpret logarithmic functions as the inverses of the corresponding exponential functions.
     16. Use logarithms to solve exponential equations and roots (or fractional exponents) to solve power equations.
     17. Use the properties of exponents to simplify expressions.
     18. Apply exponents and logarithms by constructing and using exponential models to describe read-world situations.
     19. Solve a linear equation in one variable.
     20. Graph a linear or exponential equation in two variables.
     21. Solve word problems involving systems of equations by the method of your choice.
     22. Solve a system of equations in two variables by graphing, and determine whether the equations are independent, dependent, or inconsistent.
     23. Solve a system of equations in two variables by substitution, elimination, or matrices.
     24. Find sum, difference, product, and inverse of matrices. Identify when those are nonexistent or undefined (and explain why).
     25. Solve equations in which the solutions represent matrices or variables within matrices.
     26. Graph linear inequalities.
     27. Graph systems of linear inequalities, and use the results to solve and interpret linear programming problems.
     28. Use the mod operation correctly.
     29. Encipher and decipher with Caesar, substitution, affine, matrix, and RSA ciphers. (You will not need to do the exact RSA calculations as part of the exam — you already did them outside of class in RSA Part Four — but you do need to be able to follow the steps in the process.)
     30. Determine and apply congruence classes for various moduli.
     31. Determine good and bad affine and matrix ciphers.
     32. Understand what reciprocals (multiplicative inverses) are, and apply them to the solution of congruences.
     33. Show your work and explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
1. Read How Bits and Bytes Works (through the Binary math section).

  2. Read The Binary System. Answer the embedded questions before checking your answers (no need to submit the answers).

  3. Answer the following questions and email the answers to me.

    1. Many people referred to the year 2000 as Y2K, or Year 2K. That’s on the theory that K stands for 1000, which it doesn’t. What year will really be Y2K?
    2. Investigate the y2k38 problem. Do you think this will be a real problem? Why?
    3. Convert the binary numeral 11100101 to decimal.
    4. Convert the decimal numeral 107 to binary.
    5. What is the easiest way to multiply by 4 in binary?
    6. Add 10100011 to 11000010 in binary without converting to decimal and back again.
    7. In the previous question, your answer should have been more than 8 bits long. If your computer couldn’t handle numbers larger than 8 bits, only the rightmost 8 bits would be kept. What would your answer to the previous question be in this case? Figure out how far off it would be by subtracting the computed result from the true result and converting to decimal.
    8. Convert -7 to two's complement form
    9. Use two's complement form to subtract 7 from 12

table.column:
Data Types


In this — and all subsequent function definitions — you must include a contract, a purpose statement, and at least one test case.

Do Exercises 2.3.1 through 2.3.3.
Do Exercise 2.4.2.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Branching

  1. Develop a function called can-vote? that consumes a person’s age and produces a boolean that tells you whether the person is old enough to vote.

  2. Write a program that consumes a number representing a student’s percentage score on a test and produces a string representing an appropriate comment for that student. For example, (teachercomment 72) might produce "should try harder".

  3. Use symbols for the days of the week.
    Write a function is-weekday? that consumes a day of the week symbol and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the day is a weekday.

  4. Write a program begins-with-vowel? that consumes a string and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the word begins with a vowel.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Be the Computer


Here is some practice for the quizzes that require pencil and paper and no computer.
Read the instructions at the top of the page and take their suggestion of writing down your answers before checking them.
Do these on paper or in your head. BE the computer.

At this point in the course you should be able to do exercises A-J.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Looping - Recursion


  1. Write a program called pig that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the simplest dialect of Pig Latin, in which you move an initial consonant (if any) to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "tringsay" and "easy" becomes "easyay"). You may want to use the begins-with-vowel? program that we developed in class.

  2. Write a program called pig! that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the dialect of Pig Latin in which you add "way" to a word that begins with a vowel (so "easy" becomes "easyway"), otherwise you move any initial consonants to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "ingstray").

  3. Challenging: Write a function piggy that correctly handles the cases where y is a vowel as in the word myth . It must also handle the case where y is a consonant as in the word year.

  4. Very Challenging: correctly handle words with no vowels such as tsk or cwm.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Compound Data Types


  1. Read Section 6.3 and Section 6.4 of the textbook (Structure Definitions and Data Definitions).

  2. Carefully read the Commentary on Structures.

  3. Exercise 6.3.3.

  4. Exercise 6.4.1 (Part 4 only).

  5. Define your own version of a student structure and create three appropriate examples of students.

  6. HtDP Problem Set, Section 6, #2, 3.

  7. Carefully read Section 6.5 of the textbook (Designing Functions for Compound Data).

  8. Exercises 6.5.1 (Part 4 only) and 6.5.2.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Images


  1. Read the documentation for the image.ss teachpack and the image functions in the world.ss teachpack. You can find the documentation in the help desk.
    You will need to install world.ss for the following exercises.
    On the language menu select Add Teachpack ...
    world.ss can be found in the htdp folder.

  2. Use overlay to draw some simple compound images, such as a blue triangle in front of a green rectangle and vice versa. For example:
    (overlay (circle 100 'solid "red")
         (rectangle 100 150 'solid "blue"))
    You may also want to overlay your own images on top of ones that you download.

  3. Create an American flag.
    The nw:rectangle function may be useful for this one.

  4. Create an American flag using recursion to draw the stripes.

  5. Challenge: Create an American flag using recursion to draw both the stripes and stars.

  6. Super Challenge: Create the following function:
    ;american-flag
    ;contract: num -> image
    ; purpose: consumes a width and returns a well proportioned american flag of that width.
    see Wikipedia for the correct proportions and colors.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Data Structures


Read chapter 9 on lists and then do the following:
  1. 9.1.2

  2. 9.1.4

  3. 9.3.1

  4. 9.3.3

  5. Make a template for processing a list of numbers.

  6. Use the template to define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns the sum of the numbers in the list.

  7. Use the template to define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns whether or not a given number is in the list.

  8. Challenging: Use the template to define a function that increments each number on the list by a given amount and returns the updated list.

  9. More Challenging: Use the template to define a function that consumes a non-empty list of numbers and returns the largest number. (Hint: think about how the recursion should end, it's not the empty list.)

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Design & Complexity


  1. HtDP Problem Set, Section 3, #1. Note that there are three teaspoons in a tablespoon.

  2. HtDP Problem Set, Section 3, #3.

  3. Challenging: HtDP Problem Set, Section 4, #5.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Animation


Read the documentation for world.ss.
Pay special attention to the functions for creating scenes and the event handlers.

Download the world.scm and modify it to do the following:
  1. Make the ball move.
    Hints:
    • Write the body of move-ball.
      Add dx to x and dy to y.
    • Modify the key-press function to accept the arrow keys as input.
      When an arrow is hit change the value of dx or dy as appropriate.
  2. Add the ability to change the color of the ball.
  3. Add collision detection and make the ball bounce off the walls
  4. Add the effect of gravity.
  5. Optional: Add a mouse event handler and drag or throw the ball.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Final Test


  • data types
  • numerical functions
  • relational functions
  • boolean functions
  • string functions
  • structs
  • lists
  • list processing

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Assignment


Use begin and set-structname-fieldname! to modify your world.ss progam. Notice that functions now need to know less information. Changes to structures will not cause a ripple of changes through all your code. Important: Modify a copy of assignment#10. Do not start over and do not lose your working copy of assignment#10

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Project


Your first design document will now be due. I want a copy of your write-up and a list of your data defintions. The data definitions should include struct names and the fields in each struct (including the data type of each field).

Note: Start keeping an organized folder or binder of your design documents. This will be handed in as part of your game project.

Design Guidelines

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Project Due


Turn in the following four items:
  1. Printout of your project code.
    Also email the code to me.
  2. Your original design document, (do not rewrite it).
  3. A reflection on your project.
    The good, the bad, and the ugly.
    Advice for others: what went well and what would you do differently.
  4. A semester grade justification.

Getting Started

Complete the following, and email your results to Mr. Gabriner at gabrinerd@weston.org.
Please use YourID #1 as the Subject of your message.
Label subsequent assignments similarly, just change the assignment number.
Email your work when it is complete and ready to be graded.
  1. Read all parts of the Getting Started document, and complete the lab in Getting-Started.py.
  2. Carefully read Chapter 1 of the textbook, which you can find at
    http://www.openbookproject.net/thinkcs/python/english2e/.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Data Types


Read chapter 2 and chapter 3 in the online textbook.

In this — and all subsequent function definitions — you must include a contract, a purpose statement, and at least one test case.

Download Data-Type.py and complete the following excercises:
  • Utopia's tax accountants always use programs that compute income taxes even though the tax rate is a solid, never-changing 15%. Define the functions gross_pay, tax, and net_pay.
    Assume an hourly rate of $12.
    Note:
    "gross pay" is what you earn before taxes.
    "net pay" is what you take home after taxes are deducted.
  • The local supermarket needs a program that can compute the value of a bag of coins. Define the function sum-coins. It consumes four numbers: the number of pennies, nickels, dimes, and quarters in the bag; it produces the amount of money in the bag.
  • An old-style movie theater has a simple profit function. Each customer pays $5 per ticket. Every performance costs the theater $20, plus $.50 per attendee. Develop the function total-profit. It consumes the number of attendees (of a show) and produces how much income the attendees produce. Solution

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Branching

Read chapter 4.1 - 4.8, 4.10, and 4.12 in the online textbook.

Download Branching.py and complete the following exercises:
  1. Develop a function called can_vote that consumes a person’s age and produces a boolean that tells you whether the person is old enough to vote.

  2. Write a program that consumes a number representing a student’s percentage score on a test and produces a string representing an appropriate comment for that student. For example, teacher_comment(72) might produce "should try harder".

  3. Use symbols for the days of the week.
    Write a function is_weekday that consumes a day of the week symbol and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the day is a weekday.

  4. Write a program begins_with_vowel that consumes a string and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the word begins with a vowel.

Iteration and Strings


Read chapter 6 and chapter 7 in the online textbook.

Download Iteration-Strings.py and complete the following exercises:
  1. Write a program called pig that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the simplest dialect of Pig Latin, in which you move an initial consonant (if any) to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "tringsay" and "easy" becomes "easyay"). You may want to use the begins_with_vowel program that we developed in class.

  2. Write a program called pigg that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the dialect of Pig Latin in which you add "way" to a word that begins with a vowel (so "easy" becomes "easyway"), otherwise you move any initial consonants to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "ingstray").

  3. Challenging: Write a function piggy that correctly handles the cases where y is a vowel as in the word myth . It must also handle the case where y is a consonant as in the word year.

  4. Very Challenging: correctly handle words with no vowels such as tsk or cwm.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Data Structures - Lists


Read chapter 9.1 - 9.16 in the online textbook.
Read the Google Python List Reference and then do the following:
  1. Develop the function contains_doll, which consumes a list of strings and determines whether one of them is "doll".
    Create enough test cases to completely test your code.

  2. Develop the function contains_string, which consumes a string and a list of strings and determines whether or not the string occurs in the list.

  3. Hopefully you used the "in" operator supplied by Python when doing the previous exercises. Now implement your own version of "in" by looping through all the strings on a list looking for a given string.

  4. Define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns the sum of the numbers in the list.

  5. Define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns whether or not a given number is in the list.

  6. Challenging: Define a function that increments each number on the list by a given amount and returns the updated list.

  7. More Challenging: Define a function that consumes a non-empty list of numbers and returns the largest number.

  8. Even More Challenging: Write an "in" function that is data-type independent.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Recursion


Read chapter 11.6 - 11.8 in the online textbook and then do the following:
  1. Write a recursive function that consumes a number(n) and produces n factorial.

  2. Write a recursive function that consumes a number(n) and produces a list of the first n Fibonacci numbers.

  3. Challenge: Have your code raise an appropriate exception if it receives a bad user input value.

    4. If your functions have "ugly" interfaces then write "wrapper" functions that provide a clean interface to the user.

table.column:
Images


  1. Documention for drawing and graphics can be found at pygame.

  2. Download the following files and save them to your folder by right clicking and selecting save as ...
    first-graphics.py
    Elvis
    Groucho
    Open the first-graphics.py file in Wing IDE and explore drawing graphics and overlaying images.

    When finished show me what you have done.

  3. Create an American flag.

  4. Create an American flag programatically draws the stripes.

  5. Challenge: Create an American flag that programatically draws both the stripes and stars.

  6. Super Challenge: Create the following function:

    #contract: num -> image
    #purpose: consumes a width and returns a well proportioned american flag of that width.
    see Wikipedia for the correct proportions and colors.

table.column:
Classes


Read chapter 13 and chapter 15.6 - 15.8 in the online textbook.

  1. Define a class for a Point with attributes x and y.
    Define the following methods for your Point class.
    1. An initialization method.
    2. A print method that produces the coordinates of the point in the format ( x, y).
    3. A distance method that consumes a point and produces the distance between the two points.
    4. Challenge: Overload the + operator to add two points.

  2. Implement myTunes
  3. Implement High School Transcripts

table.column:

Modify Ball.py and Ballgame.py to do the following:

      Add dx to x and dy to y.
    • Modify the key-press function to accept the arrow keys as input.
      When an arrow is hit change the value of dx or dy as appropriate.
  2. Add the ability to change the color of the ball by pressing a key.
  3. Add collision detection and make the ball bounce off the walls
  4. Challenge: Add the effect of gravity.
  5. Very Challenging: Add mouse event handling and drag or throw the ball.

  • Write your math autobiography, discussing the outstanding highlights and lowlights of your math education. You will probably want to concentrate on the last couple of years, but you should go back as far as you remember. Be sure to include specific details about your strengths and weaknesses. This needs to be at least one substantial paragraph, but will probably take two or three paragraphs. Send me an email message (DavidsonL@weston.org) that includes the autobiography and something else interesting about you. If you have a mysterious email address, like superman42@comcast.net, be sure that your real name appears somewhere!

table.column: Complete p. 365 Chapter Test #6. Also, find the equation of a line that makes an 80-degree angle with the x-axis at (3,0).

table.name: assignments
table.column:
In class, and on the last assignment, you analyzed a set of wrapping functions for a square path.

Now sketch graphs for a diamond-shape path, where the guards walk straight from each of the following points to the next, eventually returning to the starting point and wrapping around the diamond again and again: (3, 0); (0, 4); (–3, 0); (0, –4). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called diamx, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called diamy, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called diamang.

Finally, sketch three similar graphs for a circular path, where the guards walk around a circle centered at the origin, starting at (1, 0). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called xc, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called ys, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called rad.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
These questions concern the version of Newton’s method that was shown in class:
  1. In finding the square root of a positive number, what happens when the seed is negative? Can you prove that this conclusion is always correct?

  2. Adapt the algorithm so that you are finding the cube root of a number. Try out your version by finding the cube roots of 8, 9, and –8, using several seeds, both positive and negative. Do you always find the real cube root? Or do you sometimes find a non-real complex root? Does it depend on the seed?

table.name: assignments
table.column: Complete complexNewton the spreadsheet using the instructions in WS 26

table.name: assignments
table.column: Through experimentation, come up with a good conjecture for this question: Which of the two square roots and which of the three cube roots are found by Newton’s method when applied to a complex number? To be able to compare consistently, try the two square roots of –5–12i (which are 2–3i and –2+3i) and the three cube roots of 8 (which we worked on in class). Keep in mind the original conjecture that it depended on the quadrant of the seed. This turned out not to be quite correct — but it was correct enough in lots of cases that we want to modify it rather than throwing it out altogether.

table.name: assignments

1. Be sure that the following definitions are in your notebook:
    When iterating any particular function...
    • The Filled-in Julia Set or (preferably) Filled Julia Set (FJS) for that function is the set of all prisoners.
    • The Julia Set for that function is the set of points on the edge or border of the FJS. These are a subset of the prisoners, namely those that can become escapees with the slightest change; their orbit is chaotic.
  2. Complete Exploring Julia Sets I (begun in class)..

  3. Do not forget the AMC during H Block on Tuesday. This class will meet in Room 10, where you will be inspired to do well by guest proctor Dr. Korsunsky. Attendance is required!

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Complete The Logistic Map, at least through #13. You will need to know the definitions of attracting and repelling fixed points before doing this. There are good definitions at www.jcu.edu/math/Vignettes/orbits.htm:
A fixed point may be an attracting fixed point, meaning that the orbits of nearby points converge — are attracted to — the fixed point; or it may be a repelling fixed point, meaning that the orbits of nearby points move away from the fixed point. Other fixed points may be neither attracting nor repelling. For f(x) = x2, 0 is an attracting fixed point while 1 is a repelling fixed point. (Calculate the orbits of x = .999 and x = 1.001 to convince yourself.)

table.column: Practice for the final exam. Topics have been announced in the Calendar Section of our Resources page, as usual, but this time we are much more explicit. Here are some practice problems for your enjoyment. Revised solutions have also been posted.

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class on Friday, we reviewed ellipses and hyperbolas. If you wish to check your answers to the practice problems that were distributed, you can use Analytic Conics Grapher if you are using a computer that has sketchpad. Also, we worked on Worksheet 42 about polynomials in general. For homework, work on ShotSpotter Part Two and Worksheet 42.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
In class on Tuesday, we discussed Worksheet 42 and began work on Worksheet 43. Then, we started talking about the behavior of the graphs of polynomial functions and worked on Polynomials IV.

For homework, finish Worksheet 43 and work on Polynomials IV. Also, bring any questions you have about ellipses and hyperbolas to class on Wednesday.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
In class on Wednesday, we watched an (exciting) video about polynomials made by Ms. Langsdorf's former professor and boss! Then, we spent time working on Polynomials IV and V and answering questions about ellipses and hyperbolas.

For Friday, finish Polynomials IV and work on Polynomials V.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Today in class, we discussed some useful tricks for changing polynomials in standard form to fully factored form and worked on Polynomials V for a while. After that, we talked about the end behavior of functions, i.e. what happens when x increases (or decreases) without bound.

For homework, complete Polynomials V and Worksheet 44. I may collect Polynomials V on Monday, and we will be discussing our Worksheet 44 results together in class.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
In class, we discussed Worksheet 44 and then we looked at the features of rational functions and their relationship to limits. We then watched a clip from Mean Girls that made limits famous.

For homework, complete Theory and Practice with Rational Functions .

table.column: Work on WS 46 Limits of Rational Polynomial functions.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
In class, we reviewed rational functions and discussed problem 7 from the homework. Then, we started work with sequences and examined the sequences on the Introduction to Sequences handout.

For homework, locate your textbook and complete the following problems: p. 477-478 #18, 20, 24, 44, 48, 54, 56 and p. 481-483 #10, 16, 19.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
In class, we took a whirlwind tour of sequences, mathematical induction, series, and sigma notation.

For homework, complete the following problems from your book: p. 489 #4, 10, 12; p. 508-510 #4, 10, 12, 26; and p. 513 #2.

table.column:
• If necessary, read the two documents that we read aloud in class (front and back of the same sheet). If you lose the sheet, here are links to both documents: Info & Expectations and Supplies & Materials.
  • Start getting your supplies.
  • Write your math autobiography, discussing the outstanding highlights and lowlights of your math education. You will probably want to concentrate on the last couple of years, but you should go back as far as you remember. If you have not been in the Weston Public Schools all along, be sure to explain what schools you went to and when, and describe your math experience in each place. Include specific details about your strengths and weaknesses. This needs to be at least one substantial paragraph, but will probably take two or three paragraphs. You can find some strong examples from last year here and here, and some weak examples here and here (names and other identifying details have been changed to protect the innocent (and others)). Send it to me (DavidsonL@weston.org) in an email message. Use math autobiography as your subject. If you have a mysterious email address, like superman42@comcast.net, be sure that your real name appears somewhere!

table.name: assignments
table.column: We had an abbreviated period and In class, we received a supply list/syllabus. We also did a two-problem warm up; problem one spoke of similar squares, problem two was about similar circles. HW: please, get your supplies.

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class, we clarified the answers to yesterday's warm up, then worked on a new, two-problem warm up. The first problem was about dividing a square into two triangles with a diagonal, the second involved equilateral triangles. After going over the solutions, we moved on to a sheet titled, "Sine, Cosine, and Tangent: Ratios or Functions?" and worked on that for the remainder of the block. HW - finish the Sine, Cosine, Tangent sheet.

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class, we some warm up problems involving functions and simplifying expressions involving radicals. (The functions were Michael, Dwight, and Creed.) After that, we then went over questions about the Sine, Cosine, and Tangent worksheet from last time. It took a majority of the period. Late in the block, we went to the Mac Lab to work on a sheet titled, "Morphing Right Triangles with Sketchpad." Most people got through the first of four problems as the bell rang. HW - none. (We'll pick up on the Morphing Right Triangles next time.

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class, we received solutions for the Sine, Cosine, Tangent sheet and reviewed any lingering questions. Next, we did a brief recap of important review-type items that have come up in class so far; rationalizing denominators (both root and conjugate), SOHCAHTOA and its associated domain, 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles, root of product/quotient rules, and the composition of functions. After that, we talked about the idea of expanding domains and how in math, there is a recurring idea that often when you first learn a new function, you initially work in a relatively restricted domain. As you understanding of that functions expands, you often expand the domain; this is what we've been doing with Trig functions. We then did the first problem from the Morphing Right Triangles sheet, reviewed a little bit about Sketchpad, then headed off to the lab. In that lab, we worked on problems 2 and 3 - most people did not get to number 4. HW - nothing new; see me for extra help/support if you've been struggling.

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class, we first went to the Mac Lab to finish up work on the Morphing Triangles worksheet. Particular attention was paid to the Tangent ratio, and whether or not tangent can be greater than one. We then returned to class for a mini-quiz that was a single problem check of algebraic manipulation skills - skills that are so important in this course. Finally, students went back and revisited the Rhombus problem from the Sine, Cosine, Tangent worksheet; they were asked to examine the ratio of the longer diagonal to the side of a rhombus with a 135 degree angle. (It was called the Rho(x) function.) HW - finish up Rho(135) question, come see more for help if you're struggling with algebraic manipulation issues or with other problems.

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class, we looked at another way of examining right triangles and trig functions on Sketchpad - the Ladder model. From there, we developed a chart of the values for sine, cosine, and tangent for angles of 0, 30, 45, 60, and 90 degrees. These are values you need to have memorized for a pop quiz at some point; to ensure you've got them memorized, the quiz will be timed. Next, we got the quizzes from last Thursday returned. Grades were either A, B, or C. C's can be made up to B's by individual appointment with Mr. Valle. After that, we went over the Rho(135) problem. Finally, we concluded by looking at what happens to the sine function when an angle goes beyond 90 degrees - with worksheet 3. HW - have #1 and 2 from worksheet 3 completed for next time. Please bring text to class.

table.name: assignments
table.column: We did a quick practice chart of SIN, COS, and TAN values for 0, 30, 45, 60, and 90 degrees to start class. (There will be a timed quiz, soon.) Students were reminded that those receiving a C on the last quiz can make it up by appointment. We then took a look at our expanding definition of the SIN function, using WS3. In problem one, we developed a new area formula using SIN that helped us understand that when 90<x<=180, sin(x) = sin(180 - x). Problem two introduced the Law of Sines. We then worked on problem three, which dealt with an, "Ambiguous Case." HW - have WS3 finished for next class.

table.name: assignments

table.name: assignments
table.column: We began class with a review of the three major discoveries from yesterday: a new triangle formula using the sine function, the Law of Sines, and an expanded definition of sine, through 180 degrees. Ignoring the last problem from WS3 for the time being, we looked at a right triangle with a "collapsing side." After some analysis, we generated the Law of Cosines, and extended our definition of Cosine through 180 degrees. With the time left in the block, we began work on WS4. At the end of the block, most people were on #3, many having finished. HW - For next time, have WS4 completed up through #3. Also, please bring your text to class as we'll continue with #4 and 5 on WS4, which require the book.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
In class, and on the last assignment, you analyzed a set of wrapping functions for a square path.

Now sketch graphs for a diamond-shape path, where the guards walk straight from each of the following points to the next, eventually returning to the starting point and wrapping around the diamond again and again: (3, 0); (0, 4); (–3, 0); (0, –4). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called diamx, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called diamy, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called diamang.

Finally, sketch three similar graphs for a circular path, where the guards walk around a circle centered at the origin, starting at (1, 0). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called xc, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called ys, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called rad.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
1. Complete Iteration, Part 2.

  2. These questions concern the version of Newton’s method that was shown in class:

    1. In finding the square root of a positive number, what happens when the seed is negative? Can you prove that this conclusion is always correct?

    2. Adapt the algorithm so that you are finding the cube root of a number. Try out your version by finding the cube roots of 8, 9, and –8, using several seeds, both positive and negative. Do you always find the real cube root? Or do you sometimes find a non-real complex root? Does it depend on the seed?

table.name: assignments
table.column: Complete Iteration, Part 3, using either Excel or your calculator.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
1. Be sure that the following definitions are in your notebook:
    When iterating any particular function...
    • The Filled-in Julia Set or, preferably, Filled Julia Set (FJS) for that function is the set of all prisoners.
    • The Julia Set for that function is the set of points on the edge or border of the FJS. These are a subset of the prisoners, namely those that can become escapees with the slightest change; their orbit is chaotic.
  2. Complete Exploring Julia Sets I (begun in class).

  3. Do not forget the AMC 12 during C Block on Tuesday, 2/7. This class will go to Room 22, where you will be inspired to do well by guest proctor Mr. Fidler. Attendance is required!

table.name: assignments
table.column:
• Send me a description of your project topic and medium. A couple of sentences will suffice, and I need only one message per group, not one per individual. The medium can be PowerPoint, a poster, or whatever else you're planning.
  • Complete Fractal Dimension I.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Write a detailed progress report for your project. You should include the following:
  • a description of what you have done so far
  • a description of just what you still have left to do
  • a full list of all your sources,
  • an explanation of just what contribution each group member is making and is going to make (be sure to name names).
  • a question that can assess whether your audience has grasped a Big Idea that your work is pointing out or exploring.
One submission per group is sufficient: Write the report together with your group; then pick one representative to email it to me before the end of the day.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
• Prepare a small but tasteful poster to advertise the Fractal Fair. Regular paper size (8.5"x11") would be fine, although a few larger posters would be nice as well. Be sure to include the name (Fractal Fair), the date (Wed 3/14), the blocks (Activity Period and H Block), the time (10:00–12:15), and the location (Library), as well as an appropriate picture or graphic. Use an image that illustrates your own project if it looks good. Otherwise just pick something fractaly. Get it approved by me before posting it, and then post it somewhere visible and legal. We are looking for one poster per student, although you could do them collectively with your group and make three or more altogether. Extra posters are always welcome!

  • Also, be sure to read What to do before, during, and after the Fractal Fair. Do what it says, including inviting your parents and teachers to the Fractal Fair!

  • Complete Fractal Dimension II.

  • Remember to attend the talk by Prof. Devaney in the Media Center during D Block on Friday. Be on time!

table.name: assignments
table.column:
Be fully prepared for the March 14th Fractal Fair: your project should be completed before the 14th! If you have a poster, model, booklet, or other physical object, bring it to the library promptly at 9:40 on the 14th, and set it up in an appropriate place (Mrs. Metcalf will help you). If you have a PowerPoint or other computer demonstration, you should have duplicate copies, either on someone’s email, a CD, or a flash drive. If it’s on a laptop, don’t ever leave it unattended! You can install any computer materials on a PC in the Library or on your own laptop if you wish.

Since the Fractal Fair goes through lunch period, you can take turns going to lunch; Do not leave your project unstaffed at any point. Also, be sure to remember to remove your materials from the library by the end of the week, and to remove all your advertising posters on the 14th. (Please don’t remove them until the Fair is over, however.)

Back to the textbook!
p. 66, #18, 23, 30, 34 (see the instructions above #3), 36, 37, 40.

Here are the answers:
18: (x – 3)^2 (2x + 1)(2x – 1); WolframAlpha will give you an excellent graph.
23: y = (x + 1)(x – 1)(x + 3)^2
30: y = x(x – 1)(x – 2)
34: Here are some examples. Again you can check your sketches by asking WolframAlpha to graph them.
a. y = (x + 1)(x – 1)(x + 2)(x + 42)
b. y = (x + 1)(x – 1)(x + 2)^2
c. y = x^3(x – 1)
d. y = x^4
e. y = x^4 + 1
36: 5, 4, 3, 2, or 1
37: y = –2x^2 (x – 3)
40: P(x) = 0.5x^2(x – 4)

table.name: assignments
table.column:
• Carefully read the course Info & Expectations and Supplies & Materials.
  • Start getting your supplies.
  • Write your math autobiography, discussing the outstanding highlights and lowlights of your math education. You will probably want to concentrate on the last couple of years, but you should go back as far as you remember. If you have not been in the Weston Public Schools all along, be sure to explain what schools you went to and when, and describe your math experience in each place. If you were a student of mine in your freshman year, tell me in some detail how your mathematical skills and interests have matured (or just changed) since then. In any case, include specific details about your strengths and weaknesses. This needs to be at least one substantial paragraph, but will probably take two or three paragraphs. As a minimum, I suggest 150-200 words. Send it to me (DavidsonL@weston.org) in an email message. Use math autobiography as your subject. If you have a mysterious email address, like superman42@comcast.net, be sure that your real name appears somewhere!

table.name: assignments
table.column:

fidlerb@mail.weston.org
Please introduce yourself (by your full name), and tell me something positive that happened to you this summer, along with your favorite TV show.

As a result of the snow day, test #3 is today. If you are going on the field trip, you must make prior arrangements with me about when you will take it. You may bring a calculator, pencil and one 3"x5" notecard, written on both sides. It will cover the following:

1. arithmetic of complex numbers - be sure you are familiar with both forms.
2. converting between rectangular and polar form.
3. plotting polar coordinates on a polar graph and plotting rectangular coordinates on a cartesian graph.
4. evaluating powers of i.
5. solving quadratic equations, finding all solutions, both real and complex.
6. showing that a complex number is a solution to a quadratic equation.
7. raising a complex number to a power, as well as take roots of complex numbers.
8. graphing roots of complex number to illustrate spacing between roots.
9. be able to explain all of this clearly.

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class, we began by going through problems 10-30 on the Functions sheet. We also talked about horizontal vs. vertical transformations on graphs, translations up/down/left/right, and expansions/contractions. We then began work on a new sheet titled, "Functions: Graphically, Algebraically, Numerically, and Verbally." In addition to those different ways of representing data, we took notes on independent and dependent variables, domain and range, and asymptotes. We then began the three problems in class. HW - finish the three problems.

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class for warm up, we worked on a chart that reviewed horizontal and vertical transformations performed on a given function. We then went through the Gas Temperature/Volume and the Mortgage Payment problems from yesterday's class. Class concluded with an introduction/review of four parent functions: the squaring, square root, exponential, and absolute value functions. HW - be sure you're all set on the Functions sheet, see me outside class if you need help/support.

After reviewing that, we looked at the westonmath.org page and its navigation, learning about our on-line textbook. Finally, we began working in groups on a sheet titled, "Transformation Practice." HW - finish up the Transformation Practice sheet for next week.

table.column: On our first day of Pre Calculus 2, we filled out 4.25" by 5.5" note cards with some information about ourselves, discussed some of the course information , and began solving the First Day Problems . For homework, work on the First Day Problems.

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class on Thursday/Friday, we started with an Algebra Reboot activity about fraction operations. Then, we discussed the First Day Problems. We still need an efficient way to calculate Howie's total swim distances. Can you figure one out? Then, we worked on Sequences. Finish this activity before class on Tuesday, September 6. (Regarding problem 3, you should be able to find the 100th term for every (or almost every) sequence. The formulas for nth terms are harder; try to find as many as you can, and for most people that should be at least 8 of the formulas.)

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class on Tuesday, our Algebra Reboot activity was on integer operations. Then, we took some notes about Arithmetic and Geometric Sequences. You should complete Arithmetic and Geometric Sequences and their Sums.

table.name: assignments
table.column: On Thursday in Pre Calc 2, we completed a third Algebra Reboot activity, this time on rational numbers. Then, we discussed Geometric Sequences and Their Sums and worked on the Tower of Hanoi Activity. Complete this activity for homework if you didn't finish it in class.

table.name: assignments
table.column: On Friday in Pre Calc 2, we did a quick warmup activity with some arithmetic and geometric sequences before discussing the Tower of Hanoi problem and taking some notes about recursive formulas for sequences. Then, we answered the question "How many ways are there to pave a yellow brick road?" , and began working on Fibonacci and Factorial. Finish Fibonacci and Factorial for homework if you didn't already in class.

We went over the answers to the Quadratic Sequences homework and worked on Two Tricks for Adding Things Up which you should finish for homework.

table.name: assignments
table.column:
In class on Wednesday, our Algebra Reboot was about the laws of exponents. For now, we are only working with positive integral exponents. Then, we talked about how we can decompose complex shapes into simpler regions in order to calculate their area. We worked on four (4) area problems on a worksheet titled Introduction to Area which, unfortunately, is not yet available electronically.

For homework you are writing a solution to the Barn Problem. Your detailed solutions are due at the beginning of class on Monday, October 17.

table.name: assignments
table.column: In class on Friday, we did an Algebra Reboot dealing with fractional exponents. We got back our sequence and series tests. To calculate your scaled score, divide your raw score by 80. Then, we discussed some different techniques for calculating irregular areas and shared some hints about how to solve the Barn Problem which should be completed for homework. If you wish to make arrangements to do a retake of Test 1, please send Ms. Langsdorf an email.

table.name: assignments
table.column: Our Algebra Reboot on Monday extended the laws of exponents to negative powers. We briefly discussed the Barn Problem, and these assignments were turned in. Next, we took some notes on Finding Irregular Areas. Finally, we began work on A Series of Successive Approximations which you will complete for homework. Students wishing to retake Test #1 should contact Ms. Langsdorf in the next few days.

It will include everything from the last test, in addition to implicit differentiation, higher-order derivatives, related rates, linear approximation and Taylor series.
